newsitem.title: USA: software.net in deals with Netscape, Microsoft.
newsitem.headline: software.net in deals with Netscape, Microsoft.

text.p: An Internet start-up backed by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen said Wednesday it has landed electronic distribution deals with both Microsoft Corp. and its Web software rival, Netscape Communications Corp.

The software.net subsidiary of the private San Jose company CyberSource Corp. said the deals hinge on its ability to distribute software directly over the Internet and its goal of being a neutral party between the competing companies.
"We like to remain Switzerland here, partner with everyone and let them slug it out," said Kendall Fargo, software.net's director of sales and marketing.

The deal with Microsoft involves what the company said was the Internet's largest electronic software distribution deal, providing $50 million worth of Microsoft products to be delivered to two Department of Defence agencies over a five-year term.

The two agencies, the Defence Logistics Agency and the Department of Defence Procurement Agency, will save more than $30 million in packaging, shipping, installation and maintenance costs, software.net said.

The deal involves sending software packages, upgrades and updates to as many as 70,000 U.S. employees a year, including selected Microsoft products such as Windows 95, Windows NT, Office, Internet Explorer and Backoffice.

In a separate deal with Netscape, the company said it will join Netscape in a co-branded online service to provide Internet-based electronic distribution and sales of software from key Netscape developers.

The service, to be dubbed the "Netscape Software Depot by software.net," is to be available by mid-August and will offer a one-stop shop for freely distributed software known as shareware and for so-called Netscape plug-ins.
Plug-ins are software designed to extend the capabilities of Netscape's Navigator browser and other Net software.
Initial software publishers participating in the electronic distribution service include Borland International Inc., Corel Corp., Verity Inc. and private companies Elemental Software and Vital Signs.
All members of Netscape's DevEdge developer programme will be offered a chance to participate in the distribution site, which will be organised by product categories, the companies said.
In the Netscape deal, the two companies will share net margins on sales and also divvy up advertising proceeds from the co-branded section of Netscape's site.
Fargo of software.net declined to provide exact details of the split, but said "we make a higher percentage on sales and they make a higher percentage of advertising."

Even without the Netscape deal, software.net has been selling more than $1 million of software a month since February and has been on track to break the $2 million-a-month rate in September or October, he said.
The software.net business is expected to account for around $20 million of CyberSource's rougly $25 million in revenues anticipated for 1997, Fargo added.
Privately-held CyberSource was founded in 1994 and is backed by Paul Allen and more than a dozen other individual investors, with 60 percent of the company owned by employees.
